narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A better understanding of chinese culture and increased my chinese vocabulary.
I learned more new vocabulary, sentence patterns and structures, and about Chinese culture.
developed Chinese vocabulary, grammar, reading and speaking skills
Chinese speaking, reading, writing; variety of Chinese vocabulary related to many topics
I learned further Level 5 grammatical structures and vocab. The lessons were centered around topics that were directly appropriate for heritage learners and relevant to our own lived experiences.
Formal Chinese communication.
I learned advanced modern Chinese vocabulary, grammar, and culture (speaking, listening, reading, writing)
I learned more formal chinese.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think I learned quite a lot from this class; this is probably by far, the most engaging online seminar I have. Wang Laoshi is great at engaging all the students in class and encouraging all to participate and contribute to our discussion. One thing to be improved is probably organization (we had a calendar of assignments/homeworks, but sometimes homework was unclear--an email often resolved the issue, though). and timing. I feel like we often have a lot of material to cover, but sometimes we just don't have time to finish everything. Overall this was a great course--I wish I had interacted with Wang Laoshi more throughout the semester.

I think with language classes, the transition to online classes is especially rough. For one, we dont need to know how to hand write characters anymore, which makes exams much easier, but at the same time its harder to memorize and differentiate characters that look similar. Overall, I think there were few opportunities to speak and practice the material. I think maybe a tutorial session to supplement the class would be an amazing addition.

strengths: fun, relaxed, lot of opportunity to participate
weakness: NA

strength: enthusiastic teacher, enthusiastic students, good atmosphere
weakness: uneven workload, some weeks had a ton of work, other weeks had a lot less

The teacher, Wang Laoshi, is incredibly compassionate and caring. She's very willing to take the time and work with her students if you seek out help. She pushes us all to make the most of our new learned material, and the class is engaging.
The small discussion based style really made good friendships and a safe environment.
Useful material and enthusiastic professor. Since everyone had varying levels of comfort with the language, the course might have benefited from more personal/individual learning sessions

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was super engaging, again by far the most engaging out of all my classes. We had some technical issues, but they were quickly resolved after an email was sent.

I think the quizzes through chats were helpful to point on right and wrong ways to use sentence patterns. I wish we did more of those in class. I also wish we had more opportunities to reinforce our learning. We go through half a lesson to a lesson of vocabulary each class, so we are more listening to the professor speak about how to use it than actually using it for ourselves.
n/a
Professor did a great job being enthusiastic despite online format

I enjoyed the project-based assessments associated with COVID-19 learning. Group projects helped us better get to know other members of our class, outside the classroom setting. Moreover, we were still pushed to make the most of our learning material.

Slideshows and breakout rooms were useful. Most of the writing for exams was done by typing the pinyin, which made the tests more manageable/less stressful but also gave us less practice in writing the actual characters

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES, I think Wang Laoshi does a great job of engaging all students in the class and this course would've been super fun in person. She usually prepares quite a bit of interactive and experimental activities in previous years like going to the YUAG and actually practicing Chinese calligraphy, which would've been fun. You also learn a broad range of topics in this class, which definitely boosts your Chinese vocabulary.
Yes! I think this course really helped me improve my writing and reading skills. We learn a lot of new vocabulary.
Yes, its a fun class and you learn lots of vocab and grammar
This is a great course for learning and practicing Mandarin. The professor is very enthusiastic and helpful.

Yes, I generally would highly recommend heritage Chinese classes to any heritage learner looking to improve their language skills. The class is specially constructive to build formal vocabulary and literacy skills that most at-home learners struggle with. The students in the class are generally an incredibly close-knit community.
I would recommend this course to other heritage speakers who want to improve their Chinese
